awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Socio-ecological influences on the development of primate social behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
What factors help and hinder individuals in becoming socially competent and successful members of their community? This is an important but difficult question to tackle in humans. One way to approach the question is to look at closely related and socially sophisticated primates to focus on how competence develops at the start of an individual's life. This project draws upon anthropology, psychology, and cognitive research to study wild olive baboons, their social and ecological environments during infancy, and the way these interact to influence social development. In addition to providing important comparative data for understanding human social development, the project also supports graduate student training, ongoing primate conservation efforts, and community education and outreach. 

During this 12-month project, behavioral data will be collected on approximately 60 infants across two baboon troops at the Uaso Ngiro Baboon Project (UNBP) in Kenya, to study the effects of maternal responsiveness and secondary attachments on the development of social awareness. The mother is the first contact and the first social model for an infant, but baboons also form strong relationships with adult males in their group. These latter relationships may be particularly important in one troop in which mothers are weaning their infants early since the spread of an invasive cactus that provides plentiful food year-round. There is therefore an opportunity to compare the development of social competence in a group not yet affected by the extra food and one that is. Rich ecological and historical data on these groups is available from UNBP, providing context for interpreting the results of the study and clarifying how infant social development is influenced by the group's and the mother's broader ecological setting. This research will add to the body of knowledge on primate development, may inform human caregiving practices, supports training of a female graduate student, and contributes to local community education and conservation efforts.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project entitled “Doctoral Dissertation Research: Socio-ecological influences on the development of primate social behavior” supported the dissertation research of a young female scientist—Dr. Corinna Most—who is now on track to finish her Ph.D. at the University of California, San Diego.  

This project investigated the process through which initially socially naïve olive baboon (P. anubis) infants become socially skilled adults, able to navigate large and complex relationship networks. In particular, it focused on two specific factors that might influence individual variation in the development of these social abilities: maternal responsiveness and presence of alternative (or ‘secondary’) attachments.

To investigate this, behavioral data was collected on the interactions between mother and infants (to assess maternal responsiveness) and between infants and other animals in their troop (to assess both presence of secondary attachments and degree of social development attained). More specifically, in order to assess maternal responsiveness data was collected on mother-infant proximity and amount of time on the nipple; on the intensity of the weaning conflict; on how quickly mothers responded to their infants’ distress; and on whether infants displayed safe base behavior towards the mother, a behavioral indicator of attachment. To assess presence of secondary attachments the presence of safe base behavior was again used, but this time directed at animals other than the mother. Finally, to assess degree of social development a visual orientation protocol was used, in which where the infants were looking was scored before, during, and after social interactions, with the assumption that a fully developed social awareness would translate into an individual able to predict, monitor, and subsequently visually follow a social interactant – which can be observed in adult olive baboons. 

This site is a particularly interesting place to study mother-infant behavior because of a relatively recent spread of an invasive cactus species, O. stricta, which has become an integral part of the animals’ diet. This rich and consistent source of calories has had a significant effect on female reproductive parameters, speeding up ages at menarche and first birth, and nearly halving inter-birth intervals by reducing the anovulatory period that follows birth and usually accompanies lactation. It was expected that this would affect mother-infant relationships, as it decreases the amount of time that infants have exclusive access to their mothers. Although the initial plan was to compare the data obtained only to published results from other sites, while in the field it was decided that we would expand the research sample to include mother-infant dyads in a second troop studied at the UNBP, one that ranges 10Km away from the origin site of the Opuntia invasion, and has therefore been exposed to this novel food source for fewer years (5 years versus 10 years for the primary study troop).

As of this moment, only the analysis of the proximity data has been conducted and, as expected, we found significant differences in mother-infant proximity between the two troops. Specifically, infants in the troop with the longest exposure to Opuntia spent significantly less time on the nipple or ventral in the first 2 months of life. Correspondingly, they spent significantly more time in contact (but not on the nipple or ventral) and within 1m of the mother in the first 2 months. The data also indicated that not only do infants in this troop stop travelling ventrally on their mothers earlier, but that they also start travelling independently significantly earlier than the infants in the other troop. Whether the decrease in amount of time spent on the nipple...

This site is a particularly interesting place to study mother-infant behavior because of a relatively recent spread of an invasive cactus species, O. stricta, which has become an integral part of the animalsÆ diet. This rich and consistent source of calories has had a significant effect on female reproductive parameters, speeding up ages at menarche and first birth, and nearly halving inter-birth intervals by reducing the anovulatory period that follows birth and usually accompanies lactation. It was expected that this would affect mother-infant relationships, as it decreases the amount of time that infants have exclusive access to their mothers. Specifically, infants in the troop with the longest exposure to Opuntia spent significantly less time on the nipple or ventral in the first 2 months of life. The data also indicated that not only do infants in this troop stop travelling ventrally on their mothers earlier, but that they also start travelling independently significantly earlier than the infants in the other troop.
